summary: This document is an email chain from March 17, 2020, showing the U.S. Department of Justice (specifically the AG's office and ODAG) requesting the FBI to contact an individual named Ms. [REDACTED] who claims to have information on the Epstein matter. The email notes this is not her first time contacting DOJ leaders and that previous attempts to engage her have been unsuccessful.

persons.name: Gregg Safer
persons.role: Associate Deputy Attorney General & National Coordinator for Child Exploitation & Human Trafficking
persons.context: He is copied on the email chain from the ODAG to the FBI, indicating his role in the DOJ's handling of the Epstein case and child exploitation matters.

persons.name: Ms. [REDACTED]
persons.role: Individual with information on Epstein matter
persons.context: She has contacted the AG's office claiming to have information on the Epstein case. This is noted as not her first time reaching out to DOJ leaders, but she has not responded to previous attempts to connect her with an agent.

connections.description: Safer is part of the DOJ chain requesting FBI contact with Ms. [REDACTED] regarding her claimed information on Epstein.

events.title: DOJ request for FBI to contact informant
events.description: The Office of the Deputy Attorney General (ODAG) sends a high-importance email to the FBI's Criminal Investigative Division (CID) requesting they contact Ms. [REDACTED], who has advised the AG's office she has information on the Epstein matter.

keyFacts: An individual, Ms. [REDACTED], contacted the U.S. Attorney General's office claiming to have information on the Epstein case.
This was not her first attempt to provide information to DOJ leaders; she had previously contacted the DOJ about purported information.
Previous attempts by DOJ officials to engage her (via emails and calls) were unsuccessful as she did not respond.
On March 17, 2020, the ODAG formally requested the FBI to reach out to her directly and confirm contact.
The email chain shows coordination between the DOJ's AG office, ODAG, and the FBI's New York and CID divisions regarding this potential lead.
